body.p: To
the Reverend I. Leeser
at
to the Reverend
Dr. I. Leeser.
at Philadelphia.
Hague, the 17 Mai 57.
Dear Sir,

I have to repent? my sincere thanks for receiving
now regularly the Occident that valuable paper furnishes
me every time great satisfaction. I have send you last you some
? from Europe, however I have not found them noticed or
?. Did you receive them?

I heare with pleasure good tiding from my freind
d'Arcona and his family. God has given them now prosperity
and happiness after a great deal of suffering here. May that
prosperous state continue.

Did you read in the number of 15 Oct. last of the
Revue des Deme Mandes? a very clever article on Jewish
affairs by a Frenchman, M. Erqinros?? There are some misgivings
in that paper, however generally speaken the spirit is as generous
as the facts true. Perhaps you may give us some extracts
of that publication, the more as therein is spoken about the
American Jews allso.

I did converse last week with an Israelite of
reputation, the celebrated Benjamin II, a Jewish traveller
who has made exploration five years long in the far East,
in Egypt, and on the Barbarian shores, to elucidate the
situation of Jewish communities, Jewish history & He has published
a work in French, ? Années de Voyage en Orient, wherein
he consigned the first results of his remarquable voyage.
He intended now to go to the Indian Archipelago, then
to ? Indian and, if possible, crossing Cabaal
and Afghanistan to return by these remoted
Oriental countries. Our government has given him already
the necessary permission to set out for Batavia. If he
has completed his Oriental explorations, he may
perhaps visit your country and America in general. If you,
Sir, did not read still his voyage, I will
to the utmost to procure it you.

As for other publications about Jewish affairs
in Holland, I have to ? first the Jaarboekje, or
Ter. Annual for Israelites 1857, being the 7th year. It had
again some valuable papers, and poetry of note. M. Mulder
has contributed a very clever biographical sketch
of Johan Reuchlin, the human and learned protestor
of the Jews in Germany in the 15th and 16th ages; Mr.
Bortel, Historical and letter, miscellaneous. Further
deserves notice a biography of Benjamin Haas,
a Jewish (student at the Leyden university, who died last year);
the great particularity in his life was, he being unhappily
struck with blindness, he continued his classical
carreer and by the aid of friends and otherwise
he was amazed the first students of the university
his dead was very severely lamented by his parents,
his friends and professors. M. de Sola, at London
has contributed here some hebraical poetry, that
has been translated in Dutch verse. The young
Sr.? poetreiss?, ? Estella Vertzueld, has
adorned this annual with a very beautiful production,
het Gebed (the Prayer), a production of a high minded
high inspirated and deep feeling young maid. Delaville,
docent at the ? seminarium at Amsterdam, has published
afterwards last days a beautiful hebraic translation of it.

M. Lutomirsky, a great hebraissant allso
at Rotterdam, has published a Dutch and the br.
Prayerbook and has dedicated it to Miss Estella Hertzued;
who the a younger sister of that poetress; Maria, is also a ?
in prose, of great promise.

From a parliamentary paper we extract the following
exact statistics concerning the Jewish population in the
American possessions of the Netherlands (on 31 Dec. 1855).

The Portugese Jews community in Suriname counts
675 members; the German Jews 737.

The Government has approved the election of
the rabbinical aspirant M. Lewenstein, who will
be chief rabbin for the two communities at Suriname.

I believe these particulars will interest
you, and I hope being able to forward to you, sir
very soon, other particulars. If you publish them, you
will give you the trouble to make the necessary corrections,
the English not being my mother tongue.

I take the liberty in one of my preceding
letters to ask you some particulars about M. de
Silva Solis, who dead some years ago; he was, I believe,
a far relation of mine. If possible, write me something
about him and my family at Jamaica; it is but family interest
that induces me to give you that trouble.

Dispose with all liberty on me, here, and
agree, sir, the assurance of my deeprooted feelings on your
part; so believe me, your humble and most obedient servant,
